instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.R7121: What is R7121? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7122: What is R7122? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 14v. Have charger green, orange light, fan spin, and chime.
threads.message:
[PLAIN][SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 14v. Have charger green, orange light, fan spin, and chime.[/PLAIN]

I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with an unusually high <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 14 volts. I've checked <RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7122</RESISTOR>, both are fine. Before I started having trouble with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> I had a blown <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> that I replaced. Upon turning on the system and checking <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, I found it was only outputting 2v, shortly after the new <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> melted, destroying the traces connecting <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> pins 9, 10, and 11. I rebuilt those traces, replaced <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>, and replaced the ISL--had to repair damaged pads on pins 5 and 10. I'm not sure what could be causing the high <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> as everything along those paths seems to be right.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 14v. Have charger green, orange light, fan spin, and chime.
threads.message: Feedback circuit issues, <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR>/52 and/or traces or possibly bad <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 14v. Have charger green, orange light, fan spin, and chime.
threads.message: Thanks, I'll check those out when I get in tomorrow. Much appreciated.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 14v. Have charger green, orange light, fan spin, and chime.
threads.message: Was definitely <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>, thanks a ton. Replaced those resisters as well, they were only slightly out of spec. but at this point it's more worth while to be sure.
